articles.title: Children to be offered chickenpox vaccine on NHS
articles.summary: All young children in England and Wales will be offered a free chickenpox vaccine by the NHS from January 2026.
articles.content:
Children to be offered chickenpox vaccine on NHS

4 hours ago Share Save Michelle Roberts Digital health editor, BBC News Share Save

Sarah (Mia's mum) Baby Mia had a bad case of chickenpox, with a skin infection that needed hospital treatment

All young children in England and Wales will be offered a free chickenpox vaccine by the NHS from January 2026. It will be given as two doses, at 12 and 18 months of age, combined with the existing MMR jab which protects against measles, mumps and rubella. A catch up campaign is planned for slightly older children so they don't miss out. Until now, parents who wanted to protect their child against the chickenpox varicella virus, which causes red itchy spots, have usually had to pay up to £200 privately.

Ministers hope offering the vaccine free will not only protect youngsters from the severe, although rare, complications of chickenpox, but also save parents taking time off work to look after a sick child. According to the Department of Health and Social Care, chickenpox causes an estimated £24m in lost income and productivity every year in the UK. Health minister Stephen Kinnock said: "We're giving parents the power to protect their children. "This vaccine puts children's health first and gives working families the support they deserve."

Chickenpox rash

Chickenpox is generally mild but can be very severe for some people. Pregnant women are particularly at risk as it can cause complications for both the mother and her baby. Very young infants and adults are also more likely to experience serious illness compared to children. In rare cases it can cause a swelling of the brain, called encephalitis, an inflammation of the lungs, called pneumonitis, and stroke, which can result in hospitalisation and, in very rare cases, death. The disease is transmitted through direct contact between people, or through airborne droplets in coughs and sneezes. Illness can start with flu-like symptoms, such as a high temperature and headache. A rash appears one to three weeks after exposure. Some children might have only a few itchy, red spots, but others can be covered in them. Within a few days the spots turn into fluid filled blisters, which are contagious until they crust over to form scabs that eventually drop off and clear up. What is chickenpox and how can I get my child vaccinated?

Experts say vaccination will dramatically reduce the number of chickenpox cases overall, leading to far fewer of the more serious ones. Dr Gayatri Amirthalingam, deputy director of immunisation at the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA), said vaccination could be "a life saver" for some.

Sarah Mia had spots all over her body

Sarah, who is a mother of two girls, says the vaccine would have helped her young daughters Willow and Mia. Last year they both needed hospital treatment to recover from severe chickenpox. Her youngest, Mia, developed spots "head to toe" and had a skin infection, which made her very unwell. "She was just completely out of it...floppy. "It was just an awful situation to be in. "It was absolutely terrifying." She said she would advise parents to consider getting the vaccine: "I would never want any child or any parent to go through what we've been through." The virus that causes chickenpox - varicella zoster virus (VZV) - is extremely contagious, meaning it is very easy to catch from someone who is infected. The vaccine reduces the risk of getting it to near zero. And if you do still catch chickenpox after being vaccinated, you'll usually have milder symptoms. Scotland and Northern Ireland are also expected to offer the vaccine on the NHS, but have not given a date yet.

Shingles, a painful skin rash condition, is caused by the same virus as chickenpox. VZV stays in the body for life and can reactivate, causing shingles, if your immune defences are low. People cannot catch shingles from someone with chickenpox. But they can catch chickenpox from someone with shingles if they have not had chickenpox before. It is possible but very unusual to get chickenpox more than once. A shingles vaccine is also available on the NHS for: all adults turning 65

those aged 70 to 79

those aged 50 and over with a severely weakened immune system

The article provides detailed context about the disease, vaccine schedule, and expected benefits, fulfilling the criteria for inspiring good news.
articles.personality_title: NHS to offer free chickenpox vaccine to all young children in England and Wales from 2026
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Chickenpox is a common childhood illness that causes itchy red spots and sometimes serious health problems. Until now, parents in England and Wales usually had to pay for the vaccine privately if they wanted to protect their children.

**What happened** – Starting January 2026, the NHS will provide a free chickenpox vaccine to all young children in England and Wales. The vaccine will be given in two doses, at 12 and 18 months old, alongside the MMR vaccine that protects against measles, mumps, and rubella. There will also be a catch-up program for slightly older children.

**Impact** – This change will make it easier for families to protect their children from chickenpox without paying up to £200. It will reduce the number of serious cases that sometimes need hospital care, like skin infections or rare brain swelling. It will also help parents avoid missing work to care for sick children, saving an estimated £24 million a year in lost income and productivity in the UK.

**What’s next step** – Health officials in Scotland and Northern Ireland are expected to offer the vaccine too, though dates are not set yet. The NHS will also continue offering a shingles vaccine to older adults, since chickenpox can later cause shingles.

**One-sentence takeaway** – From 2026, free chickenpox vaccines will help protect children’s health and support families across England and Wales by reducing illness and hospital visits.

**Impact** – Ce changement facilitera la protection des enfants sans que les familles aient à dépenser jusqu’à 200 £. articles.title: This simple diet could help protect memory, even with Alzheimer’s genes
articles.summary: A Mediterranean-style diet was linked to lower dementia risk, especially in people with high-risk Alzheimer’s genes. The strongest benefits were seen in those with two APOE4 copies, showing diet may help offset genetic vulnerability. Researchers say food may influence key metabolic pathways that protect memory and cognitive function.
articles.content:
Researchers found dietary changes may help improve cognitive health and stave off dementia.

A new study led by investigators from Mass General Brigham, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, and the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard suggests that a Mediterranean-style diet may help reduce dementia risk. The study, published in Nature Medicine, found that people at the highest genetic risk for Alzheimer's disease benefited more from following a Mediterranean-style diet, showing a greater reduction in dementia risk compared to those at lower genetic risk.

"One reason we wanted to study the Mediterranean diet is because it is the only dietary pattern that has been causally linked to cognitive benefits in a randomized trial," said study first author Yuxi Liu, PhD, a research fellow in the Department of Medicine at Brigham and Women's Hospital, a founding member of the Mass General Brigham healthcare system, and a postdoctoral fellow at the Harvard Chan School and Broad. "We wanted to see whether this benefit might be different in people with varying genetic backgrounds, and to examine the role of blood metabolites, the small molecules that reflect how the body processes food and carries out normal functions."

Over the last few decades, researchers have learned more about the genetic and metabolic basis of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias. These are among the most common causes of cognitive decline in older adults. Alzheimer's disease is known to have a strong genetic component, with heritability estimated at up to 80%.

One gene in particular, apolipoprotein E (APOE), has emerged as the strongest genetic risk factor for sporadic Alzheimer's disease -- the more common type develops later in life and is not directly inherited in a predictable pattern. People who carry one copy of the APOE4 variant have a 3-to-4-fold higher risk of developing Alzheimer's. People with two copies of the APOE4 variant (called APOE4 homozygous) have a 12-fold higher risk of Alzheimer's than those without.

To explore how the Mediterranean diet may reduce dementia risk and influence blood metabolites linked to cognitive health, the team analyzed data from 4,215 women in the Nurses' Health Study, following participants from 1989 to 2023 (average age 57 at baseline). To validate their findings, the researchers analyzed similar data from 1,490 men in the Health Professionals Follow-Up Study, followed from 1993 to 2023.

Researchers evaluated long-term dietary patterns using food frequency questionnaires and examined participants' blood samples for a broad range of metabolites. Genetic data were used to assess each participant's inherited risk for Alzheimer's disease. Participants were then followed over time for new cases of dementia. A subset of 1,037 women underwent regular telephone-based cognitive testing.

They found that the people following a more Mediterranean-style diet had a lower risk of developing dementia and showed slower cognitive decline. The protective effect of the diet was strongest in the high-risk group with two copies of the APOE4 gene variant, suggesting that diet may help offset genetic risk.

"These findings suggest that dietary strategies, specifically the Mediterranean diet, could help reduce the risk of cognitive decline and stave off dementia by broadly influencing key metabolic pathways," Liu said. "This recommendation applies broadly, but it may be even more important for individuals at a higher genetic risk, such as those carrying two copies of the APOE4 genetic variant."

A study limitation was that the cohort consisted of well-educated individuals of European ancestry. More research is needed in diverse populations.

In addition, although the study reveals important associations, genetics and metabolomics are not yet part of most clinical risk prediction models for Alzheimer's disease. People often don't know their APOE genetics. More work is needed to translate these findings into routine medical practice.

"In future research, we hope to explore whether targeting specific metabolites through diet or other interventions could provide a more personalized approach to reducing dementia risk," Liu said.

Authorship: In addition to Liu, Mass General Brigham authors include Chirag M. Vyas, Cheng Peng, Danyue Dong, Yuhan Li, Oana A. Zeleznik, Jae H. Kang, Molin Wang, Frank B. Hu, Olivia I. Okereke, A. Heather Eliassen, Meir J. Stampfer, and Dong D. Wang. Additional authors include Xiao Gu, Yanping Li, Fenglei Wang, Yu Zhang, Yin Zhang, Walter C. Willett, and Peter Kraft.

Funding: This study was funded in part by the National Institutes of Health (R00DK119412, R01NR019992, R01AG077489, RF1AG083764, U54AG089325, P30DK046200, UM1CA186107, P01CA087969, R01HL034594, R01HL088521, R01HL060712, U01CA167552, R01HL035464).
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific study showing that a Mediterranean-style diet can reduce dementia risk, especially for people genetically predisposed to Alzheimer's disease. This finding has broad implications for public health, offering a tangible, accessible intervention to improve cognitive health and potentially delay or prevent dementia in a large population. The study is well-detailed, based on long-term data, and highlights a meaningful positive impact on a major health challenge.
articles.personality_title: Mediterranean diet may lower dementia risk, especially for people with Alzheimer’s genes
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Alzheimer’s disease is a common cause of memory loss and thinking problems in older adults. A gene called APOE4 increases the chance of getting Alzheimer’s, especially if a person has two copies of this gene. Scientists have been looking for ways to reduce this risk.

**What happened** – Researchers from several top institutions studied over 5,700 people for many years. They looked at their diets, genes, and memory health. They found that people who ate a Mediterranean-style diet—rich in fruits, vegetables, nuts, fish, and olive oil—had a lower chance of developing dementia. This benefit was strongest for those with two copies of the APOE4 gene, who usually have the highest risk.

**Impact** – This study shows that eating healthy foods can help protect memory and slow down brain decline, even for people with strong genetic risks. It suggests that diet can influence important body processes that keep the brain healthy. This is one of the first large studies to link diet improvements directly to lower dementia risk in people with Alzheimer’s genes.

**What's next step** – Scientists want to learn more about how specific foods affect blood chemicals and brain health. They also plan to study more diverse groups of people and develop ways to use this knowledge in everyday medical care. In the future, diets might be personalized to better protect each person’s brain.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Following a Mediterranean-style diet may reduce the risk of dementia, especially for people with genes that increase their chance of Alzheimer’s disease.

articles.title: Scientists recreate life’s first step: Linking amino acids to RNA
articles.summary: Researchers demonstrated how amino acids could spontaneously attach to RNA under early Earth-like conditions using thioesters, providing a long-sought clue to the origins of protein synthesis. This finding bridges the “RNA world” and “thioester world” theories and suggests how life’s earliest peptides may have formed.
articles.content:
Chemists at UCL have shown how two of biology's most fundamental ingredients, RNA (ribonucleic acid) and amino acids, could have spontaneously joined together at the origin of life four billion years ago.

Amino acids are the building blocks of proteins, the "workhorses" of life essential to nearly every living process. But proteins cannot replicate or produce themselves -- they require instructions. These instructions are provided by RNA, a close chemical cousin of DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid).

In a new study, published in Nature, researchers chemically linked life's amino acids to RNA in conditions that could have occurred on the early Earth -- an achievement that has eluded scientists since the early 1970s.

Senior author Professor Matthew Powner, based at UCL's Department of Chemistry, said: "Life relies on the ability to synthesize proteins -- they are life's key functional molecules. Understanding the origin of protein synthesis is fundamental to understanding where life came from.

"Our study is a big step towards this goal, showing how RNA might have first come to control protein synthesis.

"Life today uses an immensely complex molecular machine, the ribosome, to synthesize proteins. This machine requires chemical instructions written in messenger RNA, which carries a gene's sequence from a cell's DNA to the ribosome. The ribosome then, like a factory assembly line, reads this RNA and links together amino acids, one by one, to create a protein.

"We have achieved the first part of that complex process, using very simple chemistry in water at neutral pH to link amino acids to RNA. The chemistry is spontaneous, selective and could have occurred on the early Earth."

Previous attempts to attach amino acids to RNA used highly reactive molecules, but these broke down in water and caused the amino acids to react with each other, rather than become linked to RNA.

For the new study, the researchers took inspiration from biology, using a gentler method to convert life's amino acids into a reactive form. This activation involved a thioester, a high-energy chemical compound important in many of life's biochemical processes and that has already been theorized to play a role at the start of life*.

Professor Powner said: "Our study unites two prominent origin of life theories -- the 'RNA world', where self-replicating RNA is proposed to be fundamental, and the 'thioester world', in which thioesters are seen as the energy source for the earliest forms of life."

In order to form these thioesters, the amino acids react with a sulfur-bearing compound called pantetheine. Last year, the same team published a paper demonstrating pantetheine can be synthesized under early Earth-like conditions, suggesting it was likely to play a role in starting life.

The next step, the researchers said, was to establish how RNA sequences could bind preferentially to specific amino acids, so that RNA could begin to code instructions for protein synthesis -- the origin of the genetic code.

"There are numerous problems to overcome before we can fully elucidate the origin of life, but the most challenging and exciting remains the origins of protein synthesis," said Professor Powner.

Lead author Dr Jyoti Singh, from UCL Chemistry, said: "Imagine the day that chemists might take simple, small molecules, consisting of carbon, nitrogen, hydrogen, oxygen, and sulfur atoms, and from these LEGO pieces form molecules capable of self-replication. This would be a monumental step towards solving the question of life's origin.

"Our study brings us closer to that goal by demonstrating how two primordial chemical LEGO pieces (activated amino acids and RNA) could have built peptides**, short chains of amino acids that are essential to life.

"What is particularly groundbreaking is that the activated amino acid used in this study is a thioester, a type of molecule made from Coenzyme A, a chemical found in all living cells. This discovery could potentially link metabolism, the genetic code and protein building."

While the paper focuses solely on the chemistry, the research team said that the reactions they demonstrated could plausibly have taken place in pools or lakes of water on the early Earth (but not likely in the oceans as the concentrations of the chemicals would likely be too diluted).

The reactions are too small to see with a visible-light microscope and were tracked using a range of techniques that are used to probe the structure of molecules, including several types of magnetic resonance imaging (which shows how the atoms are arranged) and mass spectrometry (which shows the size of molecules).

Notes

*The Nobel laureate Christian de Duve proposed that life began with a "thioester world" -- a metabolism-first theory that envisages life was started by chemical reactions powered by the energy in thioesters.

** Peptides typically consist of two to 50 amino acids, while proteins are larger, often containing hundreds or even thousands of amino acids, and are folded into a 3D shape. As part of their study, the research team showed how, once the amino acids were loaded on to the RNA, they could synthesize with other amino acids to form peptides.

The work was funded by the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC), the Simons Foundation and the Royal Society.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in understanding the origin of life by demonstrating how amino acids could spontaneously link to RNA under early Earth conditions. This finding provides a crucial clue to the origins of protein synthesis, a fundamental biological process essential to all life. The discovery bridges two major origin-of-life theories and has broad implications for biology, biochemistry, and potentially medicine, making it a meaningful advancement with wide scientific and societal relevance.
articles.personality_title: Scientists recreate how life’s first building blocks joined on early Earth
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long wondered how life began, especially how proteins, the molecules that do most jobs in living things, first formed. Proteins are made from amino acids, but these need instructions from RNA, a molecule similar to DNA. Understanding how amino acids and RNA first linked together could explain how life started.

**What happened** – Researchers at University College London (UCL) showed for the first time that amino acids can attach to RNA by themselves under conditions like those on early Earth, about four billion years ago. They used a special chemical called a thioester to help this connection happen naturally in water. This method is gentler and more realistic compared to earlier attempts, which used chemicals that broke down too quickly.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because it connects two big ideas about the origin of life: the “RNA world,” where RNA was the first key molecule, and the “thioester world,” where energy from thioesters helped early life form. The link between amino acids and RNA is the first step toward making proteins, which are essential for life. It also suggests how the genetic code, the instructions that tell cells how to build proteins, might have begun.

**What’s next step** – The scientists now want to find out how RNA could choose specific amino acids to build the right proteins. This would explain how the genetic code started. Further research will explore how these simple chemical reactions could lead to more complex molecules that can copy themselves, moving closer to understanding life’s origin.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists have shown how amino acids and RNA could have naturally joined on early Earth, revealing a key step in the origin of life’s protein-making process.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques recréent la première étape de la vie : lier les acides aminés à l'ARN
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques cherchent depuis longtemps à comprendre comment la vie a commencé, notamment comment les protéines, qui accomplissent la plupart des fonctions dans les êtres vivants, se sont formées. Les protéines sont faites d'acides aminés, mais ceux-ci ont besoin d'instructions données par l'ARN, une molécule proche de l'ADN. Comprendre comment les acides aminés et l'ARN se sont liés pour la première fois pourrait expliquer l'origine de la vie.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs du University College London (UCL) ont montré pour la première fois que les acides aminés peuvent se fixer spontanément à l'ARN dans des conditions proches de celles de la Terre primitive, il y a environ quatre milliards d'années. Ils ont utilisé un produit chimique spécial appelé thioester pour faciliter cette liaison naturellement dans l'eau. Cette méthode est plus douce et réaliste que les tentatives précédentes qui utilisaient des produits chimiques se décomposant trop vite.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle relie deux grandes théories sur l'origine de la vie : le « monde ARN », où l'ARN était la molécule clé, et le « monde des thioesters », où l'énergie des thioesters aidait la vie à démarrer. Le lien entre les acides aminés et l'ARN est la première étape vers la fabrication des protéines, essentielles à la vie. Cela suggère aussi comment le code génétique, qui donne les instructions pour fabriquer les protéines, a pu commencer.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques veulent maintenant comprendre comment l'ARN pourrait choisir des acides aminés spécifiques pour construire les bonnes protéines. Cela expliquerait le début du code génétique. Les recherches futures étudieront comment ces réactions chimiques simples pourraient conduire à des molécules plus complexes capables de se reproduire, pour mieux comprendre l'origine de la vie.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Des scientifiques ont montré comment les acides aminés et l'ARN ont pu se lier naturellement sur la Terre primitive, révélant une étape clé dans l'origine de la fabrication des protéines.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos recrean el primer paso de la vida: unir aminoácidos al ARN
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos han querido entender durante mucho tiempo cómo comenzó la vida, especialmente cómo se formaron las proteínas, que realizan la mayoría de las funciones en los seres vivos. Las proteínas están hechas de aminoácidos, pero estos necesitan instrucciones del ARN, una molécula parecida al ADN. Comprender cómo se unieron por primera vez los aminoácidos y el ARN podría explicar el origen de la vida.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de University College London (UCL) demostraron por primera vez que los aminoácidos pueden unirse espontáneamente al ARN bajo condiciones similares a las de la Tierra primitiva, hace unos cuatro mil millones de años. Usaron un químico especial llamado tioéster para ayudar a que esta unión ocurriera de forma natural en agua. Este método es más suave y realista que intentos anteriores que usaban químicos que se descomponían muy rápido.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento es importante porque conecta dos grandes ideas sobre el origen de la vida: el “mundo ARN”, donde el ARN fue la molécula clave, y el “mundo de los tioésteres”, donde la energía de los tioésteres ayudó a formar la vida. La unión entre aminoácidos y ARN es el primer paso para crear proteínas, que son esenciales para la vida. También sugiere cómo pudo comenzar el código genético, las instrucciones que indican a las células cómo construir proteínas.

**Próximo paso** – Ahora los científicos quieren descubrir cómo el ARN podría elegir aminoácidos específicos para construir las proteínas correctas. Esto explicaría cómo empezó el código genético. Las investigaciones futuras estudiarán cómo estas reacciones químicas simples podrían llevar a moléculas más complejas que se puedan copiar a sí mismas, acercándonos a entender el origen de la vida.

**Resumen en una frase** – Científicos demostraron cómo aminoácidos y ARN pudieron unirse naturalmente en la Tierra primitiva, revelando un paso clave en el origen del proceso para crear proteínas.

articles.title: AI versus skin cancer: the future of dermatology diagnosis
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 27 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02738-wEngland’s health service is trialling an artificial-intelligence tool that can identify skin cancer as accurately as a physician.
articles.content:
Deep ensemble for recognition of malignancy (DERM), a skin-lesion analysis technology, is being used across a number of National Health Service (NHS) England trusts as part of a three-year evidence generation period. The trial hopes to show that the artificial intelligence (AI) tool can triage skin lesions as accurately as a physician can. The technology also aims to free up time and money in the NHS.

A smartphone is used to photograph skin lesions using a dermoscopic lens attachment, the images are then uploaded to DERM’s online platform. Developed by Skin Analytics, a software company in London, the DERM platform processes the images using an AI algorithm, which can flag lesions that need to be seen to urgently. However, there are few data on the effectiveness of the technology when used on people with dark skin tones and some dermatologists are concerned about the lack of a trained medical professional in triage.

Could AI be the future for diagnoses in dermatology?
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant trial of an AI tool that can diagnose skin cancer as accurately as physicians, potentially improving early detection and resource allocation in a major public health system (NHS England). This represents a meaningful technological advancement with broad health benefits, though some concerns remain about inclusivity and professional oversight.
articles.personality_title: AI tool matches doctors in spotting skin cancer in NHS trial
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Skin cancer is a common and serious illness that needs early detection for effective treatment. Doctors usually examine skin lesions to see if they might be cancerous, but this process can take time and resources.

**What happened** – England’s National Health Service (NHS) started a three-year trial using an artificial intelligence (AI) tool called DERM (Deep Ensemble for Recognition of Malignancy). This technology uses smartphone photos of skin spots, taken with a special lens, and analyzes them online to detect cancer risks. The AI aims to identify suspicious lesions as accurately as doctors do.

**Impact** – This trial is important because if the AI works well, it could help doctors diagnose skin cancer faster and save NHS time and money. Early and accurate detection means patients can get treatment sooner. However, doctors are still watching closely since the tool may not work equally well on all skin tones, and they want to make sure medical experts stay involved.

**What's next step** – The NHS will continue testing DERM over the next few years to gather more evidence on its accuracy and safety. Researchers will also look into improving the AI’s ability to work well for people with different skin colors. If successful, this technology could become a regular part of skin checks in the NHS.

**One-sentence takeaway** – An AI tool is being tested in England’s NHS to detect skin cancer as accurately as doctors, aiming to speed up diagnosis and save resources while ensuring fairness and safety.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un outil d’IA aussi précis que les médecins pour détecter le cancer de la peau dans un essai du NHS
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le cancer de la peau est une maladie fréquente et grave qui nécessite une détection précoce pour un traitement efficace. Les médecins examinent généralement les lésions cutanées pour vérifier si elles sont cancéreuses, mais ce processus peut être long et coûteux.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le Service national de santé (NHS) d’Angleterre a lancé un essai de trois ans avec un outil d’intelligence artificielle (IA) appelé DERM (Deep Ensemble for Recognition of Malignancy). Cette technologie utilise des photos prises avec un smartphone et une lentille spéciale, puis analyse les images en ligne pour détecter les risques de cancer. L’IA vise à identifier les lésions suspectes aussi précisément que les médecins.

**Impact** – Cet essai est important car si l’IA fonctionne bien, elle pourrait aider les médecins à diagnostiquer plus rapidement le cancer de la peau et économiser du temps et de l’argent au NHS. Une détection précoce et précise permet aux patients de recevoir un traitement plus vite. Cependant, les médecins surveillent encore de près car l’outil pourrait moins bien fonctionner sur certaines carnations, et ils veulent garder l’expertise médicale.

**Prochaine étape** – Le NHS va continuer à tester DERM pendant plusieurs années pour collecter plus de données sur sa précision et sa sécurité. Les chercheurs chercheront aussi à améliorer l’IA pour qu’elle soit efficace sur tous les types de peau. Si l’essai est concluant, cette technologie pourrait devenir un outil courant pour les examens cutanés au NHS.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Un outil d’IA est testé au NHS d’Angleterre pour détecter le cancer de la peau avec la même précision que les médecins, afin d’accélérer le diagnostic et économiser des ressources tout en garantissant équité et sécurité.
articles.personality_title_es: Herramienta de IA iguala a médicos en detección de cáncer de piel en prueba del NHS
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El cáncer de piel es una enfermedad común y grave que necesita ser detectada a tiempo para un tratamiento eficaz. Los médicos suelen examinar las lesiones en la piel para ver si pueden ser cancerosas, pero este proceso puede tardar y usar muchos recursos.

**Qué pasó** – El Servicio Nacional de Salud (NHS) de Inglaterra comenzó una prueba de tres años con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (IA) llamada DERM (Deep Ensemble for Recognition of Malignancy). Esta tecnología usa fotos tomadas con un teléfono móvil y una lente especial, y las analiza en línea para detectar riesgos de cáncer. La IA busca identificar lesiones sospechosas con la misma precisión que los médicos.

**Impacto** – Esta prueba es importante porque si la IA funciona bien, podría ayudar a los médicos a diagnosticar el cáncer de piel más rápido y ahorrar tiempo y dinero al NHS. Detectar temprano y con precisión significa que los pacientes pueden recibir tratamiento más pronto. Sin embargo, los médicos están atentos porque la herramienta puede no funcionar igual de bien en todas las tonalidades de piel y quieren que los profesionales médicos sigan involucrados.

**Próximo paso** – El NHS seguirá probando DERM durante los próximos años para reunir más pruebas sobre su precisión y seguridad. Los investigadores también buscarán mejorar la capacidad de la IA para funcionar bien en diferentes tonos de piel. Si tiene éxito, esta tecnología podría convertirse en parte habitual de las revisiones de piel en el NHS.

**Frase clave** – Una herramienta de IA se está probando en el NHS de Inglaterra para detectar cáncer de piel con la misma precisión que los médicos, buscando acelerar el diagnóstico y ahorrar recursos, garantizando equidad y seguridad.
